thought: The text extracted contains several red flags that are indicative of a scam, such as fake security alerts, claims that the device is infected with a Trojan, a sense of urgency to take action, and a non-standard contact number for Microsoft support.

There are no hyperlinks extracted from the webpage, which is unusual for a legitimate security-related site. A lack of hyperlinks could mean the page is designed to keep users focused on the fake alerts and prompt them to call the provided phone number.

thought: The WHOIS information shows that the domain 'windows.net' is legitimately registered to Microsoft Corporation. However, the URL provided is a subdomain of 'windows.net' which can be set up to host different content. It's important to note that scammers can create deceptive subdomains under legitimate domains to carry out scams. The text from the website and the non-standard phone number are suspicious and do not align with Microsoft's official communication. To get a clearer picture, I should check if there have been any reports or discussions about this particular URL or phone number being associated with scams.

[{'url': 'https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/have-a-scam-come-up-saying-my-computer-is-locked/0c174617-f500-4404-b14b-55c2bfeb2355', 'content': 'Or Windows key + X and then Task Manager etc. Also see: Open Task Manager in Windows 10 | Tutorials. And/or cutting the internet and/or shutting down your computer would stop all scam actions as well. A good ad blocker should prevent pop ups/fake warnings/alerts/ads etc. Tracking blockers help too.'}, {'url': 'https://securedstatus.com/remove-web-core-windows-net-phishing/', 'content': 'Remove Web.core.windows.net from Google Chrome. 1. Open the Google Chrome application, then proceed by going to the upper-right corner of the browser window and clicking the three-dot menu button. Once the drop-down opens, select Settings. 2.'}, {'url': 'https://community.spiceworks.com/t/how-to-block-web-core-windows-net-phish-emails-new-twist/725994', 'content': 'A common phishing technique was to use Azure BLOB storage to host content. The URL's contained " web.core.windows.net ", which gave them an appearance of legitimacy. We were able to block these successfully by creating a transport rule that blocked messages with " web.core.windows.net " in the body of the message.'}, {'url': 'https://malwaretips.com/blogs/remove-windows-net/', 'content': 'STEP 1: Uninstall malicious programs from Windows. STEP 2: Reset browsers back to default settings. STEP 3: Use Malwarebytes Anti-Malware to remove malware and unwanted programs. STEP 4: Use HitmanPro to scan your computer for badware. STEP 5: Use AdwCleaner to remove adware and malicious browser policies.'}, {'url': 'https://malwaretips.com/blogs/fake-microsoft-security-alerts/', 'content': 'What to Do If You Already Called the Scammers
If you already contacted the scammers and provided remote access before realizing it was a scam, remain calm and take these steps right away:
Terminate the Remote Session
If the scammer is still connected, immediately end the remote access session through your software’s management console or disconnect your PC’s internet.
 To do this, follow the below steps:
Open “System Preferences”
From the Apple menu, select System Preferences.
Search for “Profiles”
When the System Preferences window opens, search for the Profiles icon.
 When the “Settings” menu opens, tap on “Apps” (or “App Manager”) to see all the installed applications on your phone.
Find and tap on Samsung Internet Browser.
 When the “Settings” menu opens, tap on “Apps” (or “App Manager”) to see all the installed applications on your phone.
Find and tap on Microsoft Edge.
 When the “Settings” menu opens, tap on “Apps” (or “App Manager”) to see all the installed applications on your phone.
Find and tap on Firefox.
'}]

thought: The search results provide evidence that the URL in question is associated with scams, particularly phishing and fake security alerts. There are guides on how to remove malicious programs related to the URL and how to deal with fake Microsoft security alerts, which is consistent with the content observed on the webpage. I now know the final answer. The URL https://17apmic16.z13.web.core.windows.net/ is a scam website.

observation.reason: The website contains fake security alerts a non-standard phone number for Microsoft support and creates a sense of urgency. Additionally there is no legitimate content or hyperlinks and search results indicate that the URL is associated with scams.
